p.span: The program has two modes of displaying objects, where one of them is tied to the performance of your PC, and the other is not.

p.style: -qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;
-qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;

p.span: How does the first mode work?

p.style: -qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:14pt; font-weight:600; color:#00aa00;

p.span: Each cycle of the simulation processor calculates the movement and collision of all objects and each time the processor spends on this unequal time, this is due to both random factors, such as different speed of access to RAM on a new turn, and with quite natural, like the number of objects on which the complexity of all calculations depends. This loses the smoothness of movement, because the object at a speed of V in one second can pass the distance S1, and the other, the distance S2.

p.style: -qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;
-qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;
-qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:14pt; font-weight:600; color:#00aa00;

p.span: To maintain the smooth motion of objects, which is lost for the reasons described above, you can calculate the time that the processor spends on calculating everything, and at the time when it is necessary to move objects or change their speed, multiply the resulting time by the rate of change.
That is, if the computer spent on the calculation of one revolution T1 time, the object will pass a distance equal to V*t1,
accordingly, if he spends time t2 for the next turn, the distance will be V*t2.

p.style: -qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;
-qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;
-qt-paragraph-type:empty; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; margin-right:0px; -qt-block-indent:0; text-indent:0px; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;

p.span: Naturally, it may seem that the second mode is more desirable, because it does not lose smoothness, however, it has one serious drawback in relation to the first mode: when using deltaTime, the determination of simulations is lost. In other words, the same model, with the same settings in the program, once can give one simulation result, and the second time - the second. From this to make more or less serious calculations using this mode - it is impossible.

What is the reason? The fact is that there is some error in the calculation of time, and the same time can be calculated as two different values with a difference of 10 microseconds. It may seem that the error is small, however, it tends to accumulate, and do it by accident, this leads to the fact that under the same initial conditions, different results are obtained.
It all depends on what you need: accuracy and determinism, or smoothness.
